ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is helpful. I will recommend it to another student.

This course is mandated by the NIH for grad students in the life sciences, so everyone is required to take it. I would tell future students to go in, listen, ask questions, take it seriously, and not complain about having to carve time out of their busy lives for this class which only meets once a week - especially since there's no homework, for god's sake.

I would describe it as above: a very straightforward introduction to bioethics from a scientist's perspective applicable to conducting research at Yale. I would only recommend it to another student if they were a first-year student in the biological sciences, though in that case they are likely required to take the course anyway!

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I found it helpful to have a sanctioned forum with experienced faculty to discuss and ask about sticky issues such as sources of pressure and biases that can negatively impact our science, and where to go/what to do if we find ourselves in a moral/ethical dilemma.

In some cases, it provided insight into some aspects of my discipline with which I was less familiar (such as the review process for journal articles). These clarifications will be helpful when doing such things as submitting my own papers and dealing with ethical issues in lab (should they arise).
